PAUSANIAS.

&moesta—Pausanias deieats Mardonius at Plataea; in his pride over the victory he acts in a way to displease the Spartans (1). He takes Byzantium; treats with Xerxes in reference to bringing Greece under Persian sway. He is recalled to Sparta (2). Unbidden he returns to the army, and by his toolish con- duct reveals his treasonable intent. Forced to retum home he attempts to get the slaves to revolt (3). Proof of his treason is obtained by the ephors (4). His miserable death by starva- tion (5).

Cunorvosoov.—479: Battle of Plataea. 478-7: The Greeks free Byzantium from the Persians. 476: Pausanias suspected of treason is called home; acquitted of the charge he goes back to Byzantium. The Atheniens and many other allies leave the Spartan standard. 470: Pausanias goes over into Aeolia and is again recalled. 467 (about) : Death of Pausanias
